Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: 0-1 hours
1 hour.
3 hours a week
I spent 2-3 hours per week reading the materials for that week's class.
0.5 hrs skimming readings prior to required lectures
Approx 1 hour per week.
Less than 1
1.5 hours

This class felt like it was encouraging an "us" vs. "them" mindset and there were problematic speakers who seemed sexist.  I would have liked to learn about things that I could do; it felt like I was learning about things that are not particularly applicable to me at this point in my life.
This course was okay. For some reason, the lectures seemed a little endless and dry, surprisingly. I think they just went on without any audience participation for a little too long.

It is not in the right sequence at all. We need to ease into global health. There is the air of 'white saviourism' with which topics were chosen. Global health is MORE than that. There needs to be more basics at the beginning and a build-on. I would also like for there to be more structure given to each of the seminar speakers. Some of them are good, but some have no structure. It would help if there were consistent structure given to each of them.
It's nice to hear about other people's work however, the class seemed a little long. It would also be nice if the class was in the afternoon and not the evening and lunch was provided.
I really enjoyed the lectures, however there could be more focus on a diversity of countries (i.e. those in Asia) or other non-communicable disease (i.e. mental d/o).
The course was helpful in showing us different ways that people study global health.

It was a nice way of getting to know the breadth of people's research interests in the field of global health. It was very conversational in its structure (in that students were able to discuss themes of global health with practitioners following the lecture).
Some of the speakers were really interesting. However, majority of them weren't engaging. The topics were definitely interesting, but the talks didn't match up

Pretty interesting seminar speakers. Maybe send a poll at the beginning of the semester to help gauge what students are interested in, and bring people accordingly.
The other seminars have food, would be nice to have snacks or something for this evening seminar as well!

The course really varied depending on the guest lecturer. For some, I wish it was less about their research and findings, and more about how they cultivate relationships and help create sustainable programs in a global context.

Poorly organized. I feel this seminar would be a lot better at the end of my global health education. I know it's meant to be an introduction but half the time we don't know anything about the issues discussed. Also scheduling this for 5pm on a Thursday was a massive mistake. I have already been through 9 hours of class by this point and just wanted to leave.
good

Strengths: Wide diversity of topics covered
Weaknesses: Focuses a lot on communicable/infectious diseases, a lot of our speakers were also white and/or American, which wasn't extremely helpful for a global health context. Would have liked to see more of an international perspective and to see what international research do in the U.S. and how they apply the findings to other countries.

please include global health work done in other countries, not just african countries, and should be representative of global work that is better than the US health system- not just countries that are below the US in levels of comparison

Strengths - invited speakers from different realms in the public health field. It was truly inspiring to hear from some of the speakers and the work that they do. It also gave us a chance to speak the ups and downs that there are in any research project and how they worked through it.

I think it was a reasonable introduction to various topics in global health.  I don't think it was a great introduction to global health overall, especially for students who have never studied or worked in that field before. We weren't asked to think about our own identities, biases, or reasons for wanted to work in this field. There was only 1 introductory seminar given about the field as a whole. I think the global health certificate should start with a comprehensive introductory course, and have this seminar on top of that.

I really enjoyed this seminar. It provided us with a wide variety of topics and interests in public health. I loved getting to hear from so many people about different aspects of the global health field that better opened my eyes to what I could be doing in the future.
I liked the seminar style of the class which allowed for discussions between students and faculty.

strengths: many topics covered
weakness: discussion not always guided
Very interesting lectures and seminars but wish there had been more of an opportunity for discussion.

Selected talks covered interesting topics, but given the late timing of the course and the frequent lack of student engagement, this elective became somewhat burdensome. I would recommend both distilling the elective into a 60-min talk and working to incorporate more interaction with students.
interesting sometimes
I found most of the guest speakers and their subject matter interesting.

Some of the speakers that came in were interesting and so were some of the readings they chose to have us read. But otherwise, the seminars felt like they had no progression; they were just randomly chosen speakers. Sometimes repeating subjects and locations. There was little accountability on our end which I did not appreciate because several students would not even attend seminar. Instead, they would wait nearby and just scan the code afterward. While the rest of us actually made a commitment. And if all the seminars were going to be just speakers then they easily could have just been for an hour earlier in the day. The time was incredibly inconvenient every week.

I think this class has a lot of potential but failed to foster interesting and advanced discussions. There are three main places I think it could improve:
1. All of the speakers seemed like they were prompted to present to a very "general knowledge" type of audience. Everyone in that class is either in public health or medical training of some sort. Why did we have to sit through things like "this is what TB is" and "what viral loads are" every single week. It was frustrating because I think the speakers were not able to or not prompted to raise the truly critical discussions in global health 
2. While the topic each week was different, there was not diversity in experience or background from the presenters. Mostly well off white people doing research or working at headquarters environment. The policy workshops did a much better job of preparing us for career afterwards. When you get people who have worked "on the ground" or are actually from a low or middle income country, the discussions will naturally be more interesting. 
3. I think this course might be more productive/ interesting if we can't get better speakers if there were more critical issues raised or the question section felt a little more lively/ debate style. For example, during the Uganda midwifery presentation, I texted my friend who is a Ugandan midwife the project being presented, and he thought it seemed terrible and silly-midwives might be illiterate, but they aren't children! Singing and dancing seems distracting. But this class never felt like the right environment to have these discussions so I didn't feel comfortable raising. 
4. The last class seemed WILDLY inappropriate. It is uncomfortable to watchin a group setting 10 minutes of women describing their violent rapes, and moreso unnecessary. More than that, this is literally the only exposure I can think of in this course where students were learning about non-academia/Us-based applications of global health. How terrible for the students that actually want to work in global health!

The speakers chosen equated global health work as Africa. I think its also important to consider what speakers are complicit in the white savior complex/are problematic. Some speakers were also not engaging.  The global health fair was well put together!
I was frustrated with the course schedule because it overlapped with many of the professional skills seminars. I also think there could be a better way to handle checking in for the class.
Good seminar in global health issues. Wish the seminar was at a better time.

The seminar is late on a very busy day for me so I was drained and though the information was interesting, there were times I struggled to engage. I believe if there was a need to have it that late in the evening dinner should always be provided.
Excellent overview of topics in the field.

Coming from outside the school of public health/medical school, I really liked this course. It was interesting and I picked up a lot of new ways to look at things. It's hard to give it a general grade since there was a new lecturer every week, so it was different every time. Some topics were more interesting than others, and some speakers more engaging than others.

A strength of the course is the wide variety of guest speakers and lecture topics. However, some lectures were quite dry and felt as though speakers were just trying to pass time for the last 20 minutes of class.
I really enjoyed this seminar-- each of the lecturers had valuable input.
Good facilitator.
Nice, personable
He was a great facilitator for the class.
good
Instructor was able to present us with a variety of speakers from different organizations and that was great of him. However, I didn't hear from him too much to review his teaching.

He was clearly a leader in the field with valuable experience to share. I liked the range of speakers he brought in. But it would have been great if we had spent more than just 1 lecture giving an introduction to the global health field.
Dr. Skonieczyny was an excellent teacher and a great facilitator of class dissuasions. He was also very enthusiastic about the class and this was clearly evident in every single session.
Fine instructor - really left things up to the lecturer.
pretty good
The instructor gave one lecture himself which I felt was very interesting.

I gained very little from this instructor. He seemed out of touch, problematic, and unorganized. Anjuli seemed like she would have been a better option. Again, given he did little to no instruction, just facilitation.

Made an effort, but seemed a bit disengaged. If we are going to have a white American man with lobbying experience as the face of our global health program, we need to get A LOT better about having diverse speakers.
Professor Skonieczny wasn't too involved in the facilitation of the course.
N/a
He was always present but we rarely had any reason to communicate.

Very good course design. Would appreciate more opportunities to hear from Global Health organizations and not as much focus on work done at Yale. A balance between external and internal Global Health efforts, maybe 1 or 2 workshops would be an intriguing approach.
He was always present and helped move the discussion along. I think his choice of speakers and topics was excellent.
Mr. Skionieczny was a great facilitator, and often asked interesting questions of the lecturers.
I would not because it is not an accurate representation of global health.

Broad introduction to projects in global health at Yale via weekly lectures. This class has reading outside of class but no assignments. It is mandatory for global health concentrators. The speakers' areas of concentrations are varied and it was a very interesting seminar series!
It wasn't the most engaging course. This idea of it is great, but the execution didn't match up
Mandatory for global health people. Talks are pretty interesting.
It's fine, if you're thinking of doing the global health concentration. Or if you're able to pick and choose which lectures you'd like to see.
so good. encourage to take. learned a lot and got a research opportunity out of it.
good

Global Health Seminar is an introductory class to the field of Global Health and the different work that is being done and necessary to continue learning more of how to work in other countries. Recommend for students wanting to purse Global Health or are interested to learn more and see if they want to continue on the Global Health Track.

I'd say it is interesting if you already have experience in the global health. Otherwise its an underwhelming introduction  what is otherwise a really vast, nuanced field that deserves thoughtful reflection and learning.
I would recommend this class to any student looking to gain a broader understanding of the issues facing global health.

Yes but there need to be more international speakers. It felt very neo-colonial at times from the number of white/ western speakers. I would like to hear more diverse narratives (people from the global south in particular)
Interesting seminar series
As someone pursuing the GH concentration, this mandatory seminar posed many interesting topics. However, I felt it was difficult to remain engaged in many of the lectures.
required for YPSH global concentration so yes
Overall interesting and a pleasant way to spend a few hours each week being exposed to different aspects of global health.
No

Sadly, I know several people who dropped the global health concentration a few weeks into this course, because it just didn't portray our global health program as diverse, critical, liberal, or self-aware.
I think structural changes are needed to this course for me to recommend it. The timing so late in the day didn't help unfortunately.
Good to learn about the research and problems in the global health field. The seminar was informative.
Interesting people present but it is late so have the energy for it.
Very good course. Definitely recommended.

Every week guest lecturers come in and and introduce a topic important in the Global Health scene. I don't have a medical/science background but I was able to understand most of the lectures as the reading material given beforehand is usually very helpful. I'd recommend taking it if you're coming from another field and are interested in learning about different global health issues but don't want to nosedive into anything too heavy. It was a good complement to my own field of study.

Some classes can be a bit dry if you are uninterested in the lecture topic. However, the class does provide some insight into research and initiatives currently taking place globally. Take the course if needed for the global health concentration.
